Piers John Sellers (Ph.D.) OBE (born 11 April 1955) is a British-born Anglo-American meteorologist and a NASA astronaut.
He is a veteran of three space shuttle missions.

column2: In 1981 he gained a doctorate in biometeorology from the University of Leeds.

column1: Before joining the astronaut corps, Sellers worked at NASA Goddard Space Flight Center on research into how the Earth's biosphere and atmosphere interact.
This work involved climate system computer modeling and field work utilizing aircraft, satellites and ground support input.
He earned a bachelor of science degree in ecological science from the University of Edinburgh and a doctorate in biometeorology from the University of Leeds.
Sellers's work in the field of meteorology focused primarily on computer modeling of climate systems, but he maintained his aircraft pilot skills.
Selected as an astronaut candidate by NASA in April 1996, Piers reported to the NASA Johnson Space Center in August 1996.
During that time, Piers worked part-time in Moscow as a technical liaison on ISS computer software.
Piers has logged over 559 hours in space, including almost 41 EVA hours in 6 spacewalks.
To outfit and activate the new component Sellers performed three spacewalks and logged a total of 19 hours and 41 minutes of EVA.

The piece from the original tree that supposedly inspired Newton's theory of gravity, along with a picture of Newton.
